REPLACE, eh?

You learn something every day. Haven't worked with Sqlite much, but I gather that its REPLACE statement = MySQL's INSERT OR UPDATE statement = DB2 & Oracle's MERGE statement. Someone should sit down with these database people and make them hammer out a standard syntax some day.

Hey, whatever happened to saving Net bandwidth by using HTTP headers (http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html) like Last-Modified and If-Modified-Since to determine whether a page is new or not? Is this an evil plot to move towards world domination by crippling the Net, perhaps following your brilliant encouragement of the populace to adopt VOIP and other Net-dependent technologies?

Yeah, I thought so...

REPLACE INTO

... is the same as MySQL's REPLACE INTO. Introducing some of the database people's heads to hammers might help with standardization (well... perhaps not, but at least the person doing the hammering would have a good time).

Yeah, I probably should use those headers; maybe I'll tweak my toy script tonight (or maybe I'll just un-jet-lag myself and look at it tomorrow :-)
